column3: When Elizabeth Bennet first meets eligible bachelor Fitzwilliam Darcy
column4: she thinks him arrogant and conceited; he is indifferent to her good looks and lively mind. When she later discovers that Darcy has involved himself in the troubled relationship between his friend Bingley and her beloved sister Jane
column5: she is determined to dislike him more than ever. In the sparkling comedy of manners that follows
column6: Jane Austen shows the folly of judging by first impressions and superbly evokes the friendships
column7: gossip and snobberies of provincial middle-class life.

column3: A lawyer's advice to his children as he defends the real mockingbird of Harper Lee's classic novel - a black man falsely charged with the rape of a white girl. Through the young eyes of Scout and Jem Finch
column4: Harper Lee explores with exuberant humour the irrationality of adult attitudes to race and class in the Deep South of the 1930s. The conscience of a town steeped in prejudice
column5: violence and hypocrisy is pricked by the stamina of one man's struggle for justice. But the weight of history will only tolerate so much.

column3: Jay Gatsby is the man who has everything. Everybody who is anybody is seen at his glittering parties. Day and night his Long Island mansion buzzes with bright young things drinking
column4: dancing and debating his mysterious character. For Gatsby - young
column5: handsome
column6: fabulously rich - always seems alone in the crowd
column7: watching and waiting
column8: though no one knows what for. Beneath the shimmering surface of his life he is hiding a secret: a silent longing for the one thing that will always be out of his reach. And soon this destructive obsession will force his world to unravel.

column3: Controversial and compelling
column4: In Cold Blood reconstructs the murder in 1959 of a Kansas farmer
column5: his wife and both their children. Truman Capote's comprehensive study of the killings and subsequent investigation explores the circumstances surrounding this terrible crime and the effect it had on those involved. At the centre of his study are the amoral young killers Perry Smith and Dick Hickcock
column6: who
column7: vividly drawn by Capote
column8: are shown to be reprehensible yet entirely and frighteningly human.

column3: Born into the oppressive
column4: colonialist society of 1930s Jamaica
column5: white Creole heiress Antoinette Cosway meets a young Englishman who is drawn to her innocent beauty and sensuality. After their marriage
column6: however
column7: disturbing rumours begin to circulate which poison her husband against her. Caught between his demands and her own precarious sense of belonging
column8: Antoinette is inexorably driven towards madness
column9: and her husband into the arms of another novel's heroine. This classic study of betrayal
column10: a seminal work of postcolonial literature

column3: Far in the future
column4: the World Controllers have created the ideal society. Through clever use of genetic engineering
column5: brainwashing and recreational sex and drugs all its members are happy consumers. Bernard Marx seems alone harbouring an ill-defined longing to break free. A visit to one of the few remaining Savage Reservations where the old
column6: imperfect life still continues
column7: may be the cure for his distress...

column3: "I write this sitting in the kitchen sink" is the memorable first line of this enchanting coming-of-age story
column4: told in the form of Cassandra Mortmain's journal. Cassandra wittily describes life growing up in a crumbling castle
column5: with her father who suffers from crippling writer's block
column6: her glamorous but ineffectual step-mother and her vain but beloved sister Rose. When two visiting Americans arrive
column7: all of their lives are turned upside down
column8: and Cassandra experiences her first love.

column3: Charlotte Brontë's first published novel
column4: Jane Eyre was immediately recognised as a work of genius when it appeared in 1847. Orphaned into the household of her Aunt Reed at Gateshead
column5: subject to the cruel regime at Lowood charity school
column6: Jane Eyre nonetheless emerges unbroken in spirit and integrity. How she takes up the post of governess at Thornfield Hall
column7: meets and loves Mr Rochester and discovers the impediment to their lawful marriage are elements in a story that transcends melodrama to portray a woman's passionate search for a wider and richer life than that traditionally accorded to her sex in Victorian society.

column3: Dostoyevsky's great novel of damnation and redemption evokes a world where the lines between innocence and corruption
column4: good and evil
column5: blur. It tells the story of Raskolnikov
column6: a destitute and desperate former student
column7: who wanders through the slums of St Petersburg and commits a random murder without remorse or regret. He imagines himself to be beyond conventional moral laws. But as he embarks on a dangerous game of cat and mouse with a police investigator
column8: Raskolnikov is pursued by the growing voice of his conscience and finds the noose of his own guilt tightening around his neck.

column3: In The Call of the Wild life is good for Buck in Santa Clara Valley
column4: where he spends his days eating and sleeping in the golden sunshine. But one day a treacherous act of betrayal leads to his kidnap
column5: and he is forced into a life of toil and danger. Dragged away to be a sledge dog in the harsh and freezing cold Yukon
column6: Buck must fight for his survivial. Can he rise above his enemies and become the master of his realm once again?
